title: Calculate Interest Payments on a Loan with the IPMT Function

steps.title: Open a Blank Workbook.
steps.content: Open a Blank Workbook. Launch Excel, then click Blank workbook to get started. Skip this step on Mac.

steps.title: Set up your rows.
steps.content: Set up your rows. Enter your payment headings in each of the following cells: Cell A1 - Type in Principal Cell A2 - Type in Interest Cell A3 - Type in Periods Cell A4 - Type in Payment

steps.title: Enter the payment's total value.
steps.content: Enter the payment's total value. In cell B1 , type in the total amount you owe. For example, if you bought a boat valued at $20,000 for $10,000 down, you would type 10,000 into B1 .

steps.title: Enter the current interest rate.
steps.content: Enter the current interest rate. In cell B2 , type in the percentage of the interest that you have to pay each period. For example, if your interest rate is three percent, you would type 0.03 into B2 .

steps.title: Enter the number of payments you have left.
steps.content: Enter the number of payments you have left. This goes in cell B3 . If you're on a 12-month plan, for example, you would type 12 into cell B3 .

steps.title: Select cell B4.
steps.content: Select cell B4 . Simply click B4 to select it. This is where you'll enter the formula to calculate your interest payment.

steps.title: Enter the interest payment formula.
steps.content: Enter the interest payment formula. Type =IPMT(B2, 1, B3, B1) into cell B4 and press â†µ Enter . Doing so will calculate the amount that you'll have to pay in interest for each period. This doesn't give you the compounded interest , which generally gets lower as the amount you pay decreases. You can see the compounded interest by subtracting a period's worth of payment from the principal and then recalculating cell B4 .
